awd_titl_txt: Cell differentiation regulates intestinal tight junctions
awd_abstract_narration:
The major functions of the small intestine include absorbing nutrients from food and acting as a filtration system, selectively allowing the passage of useful substances into the blood stream while preventing the loss of body fluids and the entry of harmful materials. The millions of intestinal cells are held together by junction proteins that work simultaneously as a filter and as a glue. Most intestinal cell are absorptive cells, and it is assumed that cell-cell connections made by this cell type determine the overall porosity of the intestine. However, there are several other types of mostly nonabsorptive cells whose filter properties are completely unknown but may contribute significantly to intestinal porosity, and this project will elucidate the function of those cell types. Tissues made of just one intestinal cell type will be synthesized and tested to determine the unique composition and porosity of filters made by only that cell type. The project will advance the fundamental understanding of how cell differentiation and composition affect the filtering capacity of the vertebrate intestine. The results will be relevant to human health because almost all allergic, inflammatory, and infectious diseases of the intestine allow nonselective movements of materials that can lead to illness and death, but there is no information on whether these diseases uniquely or equally affect the filters made by different cell types. Results will be disseminated via scientific publications, magazine articles, and blogs in public websites. Research, mentoring, and teaching opportunities will be provided to international collaborators, a postdoctoral researcher, graduate, undergraduate and high school students, and local teachers, leveraging programs at the institution that target students from underrepresented groups. 

Small-intestine stem cells continuously differentiate into absorptive enterocytes as well as secretory enteroendocrine, Paneth, goblet and other cell types that form tight junctions sealing paracellular spaces. The composition and barrier properties of junctions of stem-cell and secretory-cell types are virtually unknown, as permeability can presently only be determined in epithelial sheets composed mainly of enterocytes or of nonphysiological immortalized cells. This project employs innovative techniques that not only control in vitro differentiation of stem cells to produce primary cultures called enteroids comprised mainly of one cell type, but also force dedifferentiation of mature cells to reacquire stem-cell characteristics. This remarkable technical advance enables the planned experiments that test the hypothesis that differentiation of stem cells into absorptive and secretory cells alters the expression and location of tight-junction proteins, resulting in significant, cell-type-dependent variation in paracellular permeability of macromolecules. The role of the major junctional proteins occludin, tricellulin, and zonula occludens 1 in determining cell-type-dependent paracellular composition and permeability will be examined. High school, undergraduate, and graduate students and post-doctoral trainees will participate in this project which applies a modern approach to studies that increase knowledge of how cell differentiation and nonenterocyte junctions contribute to the barrier function of vertebrate epithelia.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Mammalian adult small intestinal tight junctions (TJ) link epithelial cells, comprised of stem (ISC) cells, absorptive enterocytes and secretory cells like goblet and Paneth, to one another thereby creating an epithelial sheet that functions as a permselective barrier, preventing the inappropriate absorption of harmful compounds and microbes while allowing regulated transport of nutrients, water and electrolytes.  The paracellular epithelial permeability of the barrier not only is ascribed primarily to TJ properties of enterocytes that constitute 80% of the epithelial layer but also affected by interactions between the host and gut microbes. In our first study, we determined the TJ composition and permeability of less abundant nonenterocytes. Since this cannot be done in vivo, we made specialized organoids highly enriched in a single cell type. Although the morphology of cells in specialized organoids was similar to that in vivo, remarkably, those organoids enriched in enterocytes or goblet cells were each over threefold more permeable to 4 and 10 kDa macromolecules and their paracellular pathway contained quantitatively different TJ proteins, when compared to those containing ISC and Paneth cells. Thus, differentiation of ISC results in marked changes in TJ composition, resulting in apparently enhanced macromolecular permeability of the TJ between enterocytes and between goblet cells that migrate up along the villus column, than ISC and Paneth cells confined to the crypt.  Nutrient sensing triggers responses by the gut-brain axis modulating hormone release and feeding behavior that become dysregulated in metabolic syndrome and cancers. The ability of many intestinal cell types to sense nutrients is still unknown; hence in our second study we hypothesized that progenitor ISCs possess nutrient sensing ability inherited by progenies during differentiation. We identified nutrient sensing cell type(s) by increased expression of fructolytic genes in response to a fructose challenge. Organoids comprised primarily of enterocytes, Paneth, or goblet, but not ISC, cells responded specifically to fructose without affecting nonfructolytic genes. Sensing was independent of differentiation modulators and of glucose concentrations but required fructose absorption and metabolism. Nutrient sensing is likely repressed in ISCs then irreversibly derepressed during development into sensing-competent absorptive or secretory lineages. Because goblet and Paneth cells along with enterocytes sense fructose, sensing may be acquired after differentiation is triggered but before divergence between absorptive and secretory lineages. We next studied interactions between host intestine and the gut microbiota.  The intestinal microbiota exerts an enormous influence on host physiology, among them a susceptibility to diet-induced obesity, yet beneficial probiotic species that synthesize tryptophan seem to diminish this harmful effect. To understand the underlying mechanisms, we monocolonized germ-free mice with the widely consumed probiotic Lacticaseibacillus rhamnosus GG (LGG) in tryptophan-free or -sufficient diets. We obtained untargeted metabolomics from the mouse feces and serum as well as intestinal transcriptomic profiles. We found a strong synergy between LGG and dietary tryptophan in significantly regulating the intestinal transcriptome and the fecal and serum metabolomes. Regulation was LGG-specific and was not observed in transcriptomes of mice with other bacteria. We developed a publicly available MEtabolome-TRanscriptome Correlation Analysis (METRCA) and uncovered LGG- and trp-dependent metabolites that were positively or negatively correlated with LGG-regulated gene networks. This high-throughput algorithm can screen for significant interactions between specific metabolites and transcriptomic networks, and in this example identified specific fecal and serum metabolites associated with intestinal fat metabolism. We also discovered using METRCA novel fecal and serum metabolites tightly linked to TJ and cell differentiation genes. Barrier-modulation by these metabolites was functionally tested in cell culture, mouse enteroids, and dextran sulfate sodium-induced leaky gut in vivo. The contribution of these metabolites to barrier protection was delineated at specific TJ proteins and enterocyte-promoting factors with gain and loss of function approaches. LGG, strictly with dietary tryptophan, promoted the enterocyte program and expression of important TJ genes. Functional evaluations of fecal and serum metabolites synergistically stimulated by LGG and trp revealed a novel vitamin B3 metabolism pathway, with methylnicotinamide unexpectedly being the most barrier-protective metabolite in vitro and in vivo. Reduced serum methylicotinamide was significantly associated with increased disease activity in databases of patients with inflammatory bowel disease. Exogenous methylnicotinamide enhanced the gut barrier and robustly promoted colonic healing in experimental colitis. Blocking tryptophan or vitamin B3 absorption abolished barrier recovery. This fourth study uncovered a novel LGG-regulated dietary tryptophan-dependent production of methylnicotinamide that robustly protects the gut barrier. In summary, we discovered the remarkable effects of cell type and bacterial metabolites on intestinal epithelial barrier and nutrient sensing. This project also supported the training of over 30 high school, undergraduate, graduate and professional students as well as postdoctoral fellows and junior faculty.
